questions.text: 30-year-old alcoholic patient presents with vomiting episode and hematemesis. On examination pulse thready 120/min, BP is 80/60 mm Hg with cold clammy hands and feet. Per abdomen shows splenomegaly. Which is next best step in management of this patient?

choices.text: Large-bore IV access and rapid blood transfusion

questions.solution:
Correct answer is B: Large-bore IV access and rapid blood transfusion

  • Patient with upper GI bleeding is having hemodynamic instability. Presence of splenomegaly in an alcoholic indicates portal hypertension and variceal bleeding. Fluid resuscitation followed by massive transfusion is the top priority for management of this patient.

questions.text: Elderly man had undergone PCI with stenting 6 weeks ago. Today he passed fresh blood in stool and then collapses in the washroom. On admission pulse is 130 /min, low volume and BP is 80/60 mm Hg. His wife tells that yesterday he was complaining of melena. Medication history is of use of aspirin and clopidogrel for last 6 weeks. Which of the following investigations should be done to determine source of bleeding?
questions.solution:
Correct answer is A: Upper GI Endoscopy

  • Patient is having upper GI bleeding due to use of aspirin. Erosive gastritis / PUD would have caused melena initially and later haematochezia.
  • Colonoscopy is typically reserved for when upper GI endoscopy is negative or when bleeding is clearly from the lower GI tract.
  • Stool occult blood testing is not useful here because the bleeding is overt, and the patient is unstable.
  • Abdominal ultrasound will not help in identifying the source of GI bleeding.

questions.text: Alcoholic patient with bleeding oesophageal varices is stabilized in ICU. Which of the following interventions will be done in this patient to prevent recurrence of such an event?
questions.solution:
Correct answer is A: Endoscopic variceal ligation

  • Endoscopic variceal ligation is the primary recommended procedure for both emergency control and secondary prevention of esophageal variceal bleeding.
  • After initial EVL therapy, repeat sessions are often needed until varices are eradicated or sufficiently reduced.
  • Medical therapies such as vasoactive drugs (octreotide or terlipressin) are used acutely to control bleeding and as adjuncts but are not sufficient alone for long-term prevention.
  • Trans-jugular intrahepatic portosystemic shunting (TIPS) is generally reserved for patients who fail endoscopic and medical therapy or have recurrent bleeding.

questions.text: Patient with upper GI bleeding and pedal oedema is found to have ‘cerebriform appearance of stomach mucosa’ on UGI endoscopy. Diagnosis is?
questions.solution:
Correct answer is B: Menetrier disease

  • Menetrier disease is a rare hypertrophic gastropathy characterized by enlarged, thickened gastric folds with a characteristic cerebriform /brain-like convoluted appearance on endoscopy.
  • The disease features foveolar hyperplasia (proliferation of mucus-secreting cells), leading to thickened gastric folds visible endoscopically with this distinctive appearance.

questions.text: Which of the following is most common site of Mallory Weiss syndrome?
questions.solution:
Correct answer is C: Lower 0esophageal sphincter

  • Mallory-Weiss tears are longitudinal mucosal lacerations typically located at or just below the gastroesophageal junction, where the lower oesophageal sphincter is situated. This mucosal laceration is non-life threatening in nature due to submucosal tear.

questions.text: Alcoholic went for a party and did binge drinking. He developed coffee ground vomitus episodes and developed cold clammy extremities. Post volume resuscitation UGI endoscopy was done revealed a ulcer in first part of duodenum. Which of the tests will be done to determine the aetiology of this presentation?

choices.text: Doppler to measure portal vein pressure

questions.solution:
Correct answer is B: Urease test

  • Duodenal ulcers are most commonly caused by Helicobacter pylori infection, especially in a context of acute upper GI bleeding. The urease test detects H. pylori, which produces urease enzyme.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Ultrasound abdomen for liver echotexture: Useful for alcoholic liver disease and check for ascites, splenomegaly which indicate portal hypertension.

Option C - Doppler to measure portal vein pressure : This is ruled out as question itself mentions ulcer in D1. 

Option D - Oesophageal manometry: Used for motility disorders, not for ulcer aetiology.

questions.text: H. Pylori can lead to development of all of the following except?
questions.solution:
Correct answer is D - Barrett oesophagus:

  • Barrett oesophagus is linked to GERD and not linked to H. pylori infection. Harrison mentions an inverse relationship with H. pylori infection reducing the risk of developing Barrett oesophagus
  • H. Pylori is class I carcinogen and leads to gastric adenocarcinoma and MALToma. The hyperchlorhydria state induced by this bacteria explains the development of duodenal ulcer.

questions.text: You have given triple therapy to a patient with documented H. Pylori infection by urease test. Which is correct about follow up of this patient?

choices.text: Call after 4 weeks of treatment completion and do urea breath test
Call after 4 weeks of treatment completion and do repeat endoscopy
Call after 4 weeks of treatment completion and do stool PCR for toxin A and toxin B
Call after 4 weeks of treatment completion and give reassurance

questions.solution:
Correct answer is A: Call after 4 weeks of treatment completion and do urea breath test

  • The guidelines are wait at least 1 month after treatment finishes. During that period no antibiotics, bismuth compounds, or proton pump inhibitors are to be given as these can influence test accuracy.
  • Subsequently the patient is to be tested with either UBT or stool antigen for H. Pylori. In summary UBT is used not only for screening for documentation of eradication of infection. Note option C is for clostridium difficile infection and not H. pylori.

questions.text: 60 year old obese man is having osteoarthritis and he is taking ibuprofen daily for the past 3 months. He developed epigastric pain and occult GI bleeding. Which of the following is correct about the cause?

choices.text: PGE2 and prostacyclin production reduced with decreased mucosal barrier
Increased acid production due to ibuprofen
PGE1 and prostacyclin production reduced with decreased mucosal barrier
Mucosal injury due to inhibition of COX-2

questions.solution:
Correct answer is A: PGE2 and prostacyclin production reduced with decreased mucosal barrier

  • Ibuprofen is a non-steroidal anti-inflammatory drug (NSAID) that inhibits cyclooxygenase enzymes (COX-1 and COX-2). This inhibition decreases the synthesis of protective prostaglandins, especially PGE2 and prostacyclin (PGI2), in the gastric mucosa.

questions.text: 30-year-old alcoholic male presents with diffuse abdominal pain and prostration. On examination guarding and rigidity of anterior abdominal wall is noted. Urgent X ray abdomen is done. Past medical records show multiple hospital visits for epigastric pain and positive “clo test’. Which of the following is the cause of this presentation?
questions.solution:
Correct answer is A: Viscus perforation

  • Guarding and rigidity of the abdomen are classic signs of peritonitis, which occurs when there is leakage of gastrointestinal contents into the peritoneal cavity causing inflammation. Positive Clo test implies positive urease test. The patient is having H. Pylori infection that would have caused PUD. Due to possible lack of compliance with medication, he has currently developed viscus perforation.
  • X- Ray shows gas under the diaphragm that rules out option b,c and d.

questions.text: A 65-year-old patient with a history of atrial fibrillation presents with vomiting and sudden onset severe diffuse abdominal pain that is disproportionate to physical examination findings. On examination, the abdomen is soft with minimal tenderness, but tachycardia is noted. Laboratory studies reveal elevated lactate levels. What is the most appropriate next step to confirm the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct answer is B: CT angiography

  • Atrial fibrillation is a common risk factor for embolic events, including embolism to the mesenteric arteries. The hallmark clinical feature is severe abdominal pain that is disproportionate to physical findings (soft abdomen with minimal tenderness) and clinical diagnosis is acute mesenteric insufficiency.
  • Elevated lactate indicates tissue hypoperfusion and ischemia. Tachycardia is a response to pain and early systemic stress.
  • Hence the most appropriate next step is to perform CT angiography of the mesenteric vessels

questions.text: HIV positive truck driver presents with odynophagia. UGIE shows serpiginous ulcers in oesophagus. Biopsy from ulcer base shows basophilic intranuclear and intracytoplasmic bodies. Which is the likely cause of this presentation?
questions.solution:
Correct answer is B: CMV

  • The key word is serpiginous ulcers in oesophagus with histological finding of basophilic intranuclear and intracytoplasmic inclusion bodies that is seen with CMV.
  • Herpes Simplex Virus esophagitis usually presents with small, discrete, "punched-out / volcano" ulcers and intranuclear inclusions only.

questions.text: 40-year-old female patient presents with dysphagia for past one year to solid food items . On examination, she has pallor with cheilosis and koilonychia. The diagnosis is?
questions.solution:
Correct answer is A: Plummer Vinson syndrome

  • Plummer Vinson syndrome is characterized by the classical triad of dysphagia, iron deficiency anaemia, and oesophageal webs.
  • Dysphagia in PVS is due to esophageal webs leading to difficulty swallowing, typically solids.

questions.text: Which of the following conditions will have "watermelon appearance of stomach mucosa" on upper GI endoscopy?
questions.solution:
Correct answer is Gastric antral vascular ectasia:

  • In GAVE, longitudinal columns of ectatic mucosal vessels radiate outward from the pylorus, resembling the stripes of a watermelon. It can also be seen in patients with systemic sclerosis. It presents with chronic blood loss
  • Histology: fibromuscular hyperplasia, spindle cell proliferation, and capillary ectasia in the lamina propria.

Incorrect Options:

  • Menetrier disease presents with giant rugal folds due to protein-losing gastropathy, not vascular stripes.
  • MALToma occurs due to H.Pylori and presents as a nodularity or ulceration
  • GIST is a stromal tumor and presents as a submucosal mass
